user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_ModuleSymbolLookup:
```c
int32 OS_ModuleSymbolLookup(osal_id_t module_id, cpuaddr *symbol_address, const char *symbol_name)
{
    int32               return_code;
    int32               staticsym_status;
    OS_common_record_t *record;
    OS_object_token_t   token;

    /*
    ** Check parameters
    */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(symbol_address);
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(symbol_name);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, module_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_global_module_table, token);

        return_code = OS_ModuleSymbolLookup_Impl(&token, symbol_address, symbol_name);
        if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
        {
            /* look for a static symbol that also matches this module name */
            staticsym_status = OS_SymbolLookup_Static(symbol_address, symbol_name, record->name_entry);

            /*
             * Only overwrite the return code if static lookup was successful.
             * Otherwise keep the error code from the low level implementation.
             */
            if (staticsym_status == OS_SUCCESS)
            {
                return_code = staticsym_status;
            }
        }

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
return_code = OS_ModuleSymbolLookup_Impl(&token, symbol_address, symbol_name);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.8 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation in this call as written: passing &token allows the callee to modify the object pointed-to (the token) which is permitted. A Rule 17.8 violation would occur only if the callee modiﬁes its pointer parameter itself — for example, if OS_ModuleSymbolLookup_Impl had a signature like int32 OS_ModuleSymbolLookup_Impl(OS_object_token_t *token, ...) and inside did token = NULL; or token = &other_token; (or took OS_object_token_t ** and assigned the pointer parameter), that assignment to the pointer parameter would breach Rule 17.8.
